importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article reflects the current situation in Gaza regarding food supply shortages and humanitarian aid access, highlighting the urgency of the crisis as of late October 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline centers on the current humanitarian crisis in Gaza following the US-brokered ceasefire, emphasizing the immediate need for increased aid deliveries and cross-border access.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza remain critically low, with only 750 metric tons of food entering daily—far below the WFP's target of 2,000 tonnes.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings (Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara) are currently open, severely limiting aid access.
The WFP operates 26 food distribution points, up from five, but still far short of the 145 it aims to run across Gaza.
Humanitarian aid has reached northern Gaza via the south, but large-scale convoys to Gaza City and the north have not occurred due to restrictions.
The WFP has not been granted access to the Salah al-Din Street, a major north-south route, preventing full distribution.
The ceasefire brokered by US President Donald Trump is considered vital to sustaining aid delivery and preventing famine.
Hamas has pledged to return 28 bodies of captured Israeli soldiers, having delivered 13 so far, with the Rafah crossing remaining closed until further notice.
Palestinian civilians are rationing food due to uncertainty about the ceasefire's durability and future conflict risks.

namedEntities.name: UN World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A UN agency responsible for coordinating food aid to vulnerable populations worldwide.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is central to the current crisis, reporting on the shortfall in food deliveries to Gaza and calling for more crossings to be opened to increase aid access.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza in the southern part of the territory.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the two currently open crossings into Gaza, enabling limited food deliveries to the southern regions of Gaza.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara (Kerem Shalom in Israel)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza located in the central region.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the two operational crossings, contributing to the limited flow of food and aid into central Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing between Gaza and Egypt, currently closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its closure significantly restricts humanitarian access and is tied to Hamas’s pledge to return Israeli captives' remains.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major north-south road in Gaza that has not been opened to the WFP for aid distribution.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP has not been granted access to this key route, limiting aid to the northern parts of Gaza and preventing equitable distribution.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian political and military organization with control over parts of Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is involved in the hostage return agreement and maintains control over key access points, influencing the flow of humanitarian aid and ceasefire conditions.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Prime Minister of Israel, who has publicly stated that the Rafah crossing remains closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His position on keeping Rafah closed until Hamas hands over captives directly affects humanitarian access to northern Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President who brokered a ceasefire in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ceasefire agreement he facilitated is seen as essential for sustaining aid deliveries and preventing famine in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A militant wing of Hamas responsible for military operations in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Qassam Brigades announced the return of two Israeli captives' bodies, signaling compliance with the hostage exchange agreement.

namedEntities.name: 28 Israeli captives
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A number of Israeli soldiers captured during the war in Gaza, with 13 bodies returned as of the article’s date.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The return of these captives’ bodies is a key condition for the reopening of crossings and the stability of the ceasefire.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that food supplies to Gaza remain critically insufficient, with only 750 metric tons of aid entering daily—well below the target of 2,000 tonnes—due to just two open crossings: Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara. Despite an increase from five to 26 distribution points, the WFP emphasizes that full access is missing, especially in northern Gaza, where the Salah al-Din Street remains blocked. The ceasefire brokered by US President Donald Trump is cited as vital for sustaining humanitarian access, while Hamas has returned 13 of 28 pledged captives’ bodies. The Rafah crossing remains closed until further notice, and civilians are rationing food due to fears of renewed conflict or supply collapse.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
